defs.docs: Calloop, a Callback-based Event Loop

attributes.value: / Calloop, a Callback-based Event Loop
/ This crate provides an `EventLoop` type, which is a small abstraction
/ over a polling system. The main difference between this crate
/ and other traditional rust event loops is that it is based on callbacks:
/ you can register several event sources, each being associated with a callback
/ closure that will be invoked whenever the associated event source generates
/ events.
/ This crate was initially an implementation detail of `wayland-server`, and has been
/ split-off for reuse. I expect it to be more useful for GUI programs or graphical
/ servers (like wayland-based apps) than performance critial networking code, which are
/ more versed towards `tokio` and async-await. It mostly shines in the conception of
/ modular infrastructures, allowing different modules to use the same event loop without
/ needing to know about each other.
/ ## How to use it
/ extern crate calloop;
/ use std::time::Duration;
/ fn main() {
/     // Create the event loop
/     let mut event_loop = calloop::EventLoop::new().expect("Failed to initialize the event loop!");
/     // Retrieve an handle. It is used to insert new sources into the event loop
/     // It can be cloned, allowing you to insert sources from within sources
/     let handle = event_loop.handle();
/      * Setup your program, inserting event sources in the loop
/     // Actual run of your loop
/     loop {
/         // Dispatch received events to their callbacks, waiting at most 20 ms for
/         // new events
/         // The `&mut shared_data` is a mutable reference that will be forwarded to all
/         // your callbacks, allowing them to easily share some state
/ #       let mut shared_data = ();
/         event_loop.dispatch(Duration::from_millis(20), &mut shared_data);
/          * Insert here the processing you need to do do between each event loop run
/          * like your drawing logic if you're doing a GUI app for example.
/ #        break;
/ ## Event source types
/ The event loop is backed by an OS provided polling selector (epoll on Linux).
/ This crate also provide some adapters for common event sources such as:
/ - MPSC channels
/ - Timers
/ - unix signals
/ As well as generic objects backed by file descriptors.
/ It is also possible to insert "idle" callbacks. These callbacks represent computations that
/ need to be done at some point, but are not as urgent as processing the events. These callbacks
/ are stored and then executed during `EventLoop::dispatch(..)`, once all events from the sources
/ have been processed.
/ ## Custom event sources
/ You can create custom event sources can will be inserted in the event loop by
/ implementing the `EventSource` trait. This can be done either directly from the file
/ descriptors of your source of interest, or by wrapping an other event source and further
/ processing its events. An `EventSource` can register more than one file descriptor and
/ aggregate them.
warn(missing_docs)

defs.name: OneShot
defs.docs: Single event generation

attributes.value: / Single event generation
/ This FD will be disabled as soon as it has generated one event.
/ The user will need to use `LoopHandle::update()` to re-enable it if
/ desired.

defs.name: Level
defs.docs: Level-triggering

attributes.value: / Level-triggering
/ This FD will report events on every poll as long as the requested interests
/ are available. If the same FD is inserted in multiple event loops, all of
/ them are notified of readiness.

defs.name: Edge
defs.docs: Edge-triggering

attributes.value: / Edge-triggering
/ This FD will report events only when it *gains* one of the requested interests.
/ it must thus be fully processed befor it'll generate events again. If the same
/ FD is inserted on multiple event loops, it may be that not all of them are notified
/ of readiness, and not necessarily always the same(s) (at least one is notified).

defs.name: Token
defs.docs: A Token for registration

attributes.value: / A Token for registration
/ This token is given to you by the event loop, and you should
/ forward it to the `Poll` when registering your file descriptors.
/ It also contains a publc field that you can change. In case your event
/ source needs to register more than one FD, you can register each with a
/ different value of the `sub_id` field, to differentiate them. You can then
/ know which of these FD is ready by reading the `sub_id` field of the
/ token you'll be given in the `process_events` method of your source.

defs.name: sub_id
defs.docs: The source-internal ID

attributes.value: / The source-internal ID

defs.name: Poll
defs.docs: The polling system

attributes.value: / The polling system
/ This type represents the polling system of calloop, on which you
/ can register your file descriptors. This interface is only accessible in
/ implementations of the `EventSource` trait.
/ You only need to interact with this type if you are implementing you
/ own event sources, while implementing the `EventSource` trait. And even in this case,
/ you can often just use the `Generic` event source and delegate the implementations to it.

defs.value: pub fn register(&mut Self, RawFd, Interest, Mode, Token) -> io::Result<()>
defs.docs: Register a new file descriptor for polling

attributes.value: / Register a new file descriptor for polling
/ The file descriptor will be registered with given interest,
/ mode and token. This function will fail if given a
/ bad file descriptor or if the provided file descriptor is already
/ registered.

defs.docs: Update the registration for a file descriptor

attributes.value: / Update the registration for a file descriptor
/ This allows you to change the interest, mode or token of a file
/ descriptor. Fails if the provided fd is not currently registered.

defs.docs: Unregister a file descriptor

attributes.value: / Unregister a file descriptor
/ This file descriptor will no longer generate events. Fails if the
/ provided file descriptor is not currently registered.

defs.name: LoopHandle
defs.docs: An handle to an event loop

attributes.value: / An handle to an event loop
/ This handle allows you to insert new sources and idles in this event loop,
/ it can be cloned, and it is possible to insert new sources from within a source
/ callback.

defs.value:
pub fn insert_source<S, F>(&Self, S, F) -> Result<Source<S>, InsertError<S>>
where S: EventSource + 'static,
F: FnMut(S::Event, &mut S::Metadata, &mut Data) -> S::Ret + 'static
defs.docs: Insert an new event source in the loop

attributes.value: / Insert an new event source in the loop
/ The provided callback will be called during the dispatching cycles whenever the
/ associated source generates events, see `EventLoop::dispatch(..)` for details.

defs.name: insert_idle
defs.value: pub fn insert_idle<F: FnOnce(&mut Data) -> () + 'static>(&Self, F) -> Idle
defs.docs: Insert an idle callback

attributes.value: / Insert an idle callback
/ This callback will be called during a dispatching cycle when the event loop has
/ finished processing all pending events from the sources and becomes idle.

defs.name: with_source
defs.value:
pub fn with_source<S: EventSource + 'static, T, F: FnOnce(&mut S) ->
                   T>(&Self, &Source<S>, F) -> T
defs.docs: Access this event source

attributes.value: / Access this event source
/ This allows you to modify the event source without removing it from the event
/ loop if it allows it.
/ Note that replacing it with an other using `mem::replace` or equivalent would not
/ correctly update its registration and generate errors. Instead you should remove
/ the source using the `remove()` method and then insert a new one.
/ **Note**: This cannot be done from within the callback of the same source.

defs.name: enable
defs.docs: Enable this previously disabled event source

attributes.value: / Enable this previously disabled event source
/ This previously disabled source will start generating events again.
/ **Note**: This cannot be done from within the callback of the same source.

defs.name: update
defs.docs: Make this source update its registration

attributes.value: / Make this source update its registration
/ If after accessing the source you changed its parameters in a way that requires
/ updating its registration.
/ **Note**: This cannot be done from within the callback of the same source.

defs.name: disable
defs.docs: Disable this event source

attributes.value: / Disable this event source
/ The source remains in the event loop, but it'll no longer generate events
/ **Note**: This cannot be done from within the callback of the same source.

defs.name: remove
defs.value: pub fn remove<S: EventSource + 'static>(&Self, Source<S>) -> S
defs.docs: Remove this source from the event loop

attributes.value: / Remove this source from the event loop
/ You are givent the `EventSource` back.
/ **Note**: This cannot be done from within the callback of the same source.

defs.name: kill
defs.docs: Remove this event source from the event loop and drop it

attributes.value: / Remove this event source from the event loop and drop it
/ The source is not given back to you but instead dropped
/ **Note**: This *can* be done from within the callback of the same source

defs.name: EventLoop
defs.docs: An event loop

attributes.value: / An event loop
/ This loop can host several event sources, that can be dynamically added or removed.

defs.docs: Create a new event loop

attributes.value: / Create a new event loop
/ Fails if the initialization of the polling system failed.

attributes.value: / Retrieve a loop handle

defs.name: dispatch
defs.value:
pub fn dispatch<D: Into<Option<Duration>>>(&mut Self, D, &mut Data)
-> io::Result<()>
defs.docs: Dispatch pending events to their callbacks

attributes.value: / Dispatch pending events to their callbacks
/ Some source have events available, their callbacks will be immediatly called.
/ Otherwise this will wait until an event is receive or the provided `timeout`
/ is reached. If `timeout` is `None`, it will wait without a duration limit.
/ Once pending events have been processed or the timeout is reached, all pending
/ idle callbacks will be fired before this method returns.

defs.name: get_signal
defs.docs: Get a signal to stop this event loop from running

attributes.value: / Get a signal to stop this event loop from running
/ To be used in conjunction with the `run()` method.

defs.name: run
defs.value:
pub fn run<F>(&mut Self, Option<Duration>, &mut Data, F) -> io::Result<()>
where F: FnMut(&mut Data) -> ()
defs.docs: Run this event loop

attributes.value: / Run this event loop
/ This will repeatedly try to dispatch events (see the `dispatch()` method) on
/ this event loop, waiting at most `timeout` every time.
/ Between each dispatch wait, your provided callback will be called.
/ You can use the `get_signal()` method to retrieve a way to stop or wakeup
/ the event loop from anywhere.

defs.name: LoopSignal
defs.docs:
A signal that can be shared between thread to stop or wakeup a running
 event loop

attributes.value: / A signal that can be shared between thread to stop or wakeup a running
/ event loop

defs.name: stop
defs.docs: Stop the event loop

attributes.value: / Stop the event loop
/ Once this method is called, the next time the event loop has finished
/ waiting for events, it will return rather than starting to wait again.
/ This is only usefull if you are using the `EventLoop::run()` method.

defs.name: wakeup
defs.docs: Wake up the event loop

attributes.value: / Wake up the event loop
/ This sends a dummy event to the event loop to simulate the reception
/ of an event, making the wait return early. Called after `stop()`, this
/ ensures the event loop will terminate quickly if you specified a long
/ timeout (or no timeout at all) to the `dispatch` or `run` method.

defs.name: channel
defs.docs: An MPSC channel whose receiving end is an event source

attributes.value: / An MPSC channel whose receiving end is an event source
/ Create a channel using `Channel::<T>::new()`, which returns a
/ `Sender<T>` that can be cloned and sent accross threads if `T: Send`,
/ and a `Channel<T>` that can be inserted into an `EventLoop`. It will generate
/ one event per message.

defs.name: Msg
defs.docs: A message was received and is bundled here

attributes.value: / A message was received and is bundled here

defs.name: Closed
defs.docs: The channel was closed

attributes.value: / The channel was closed
/ This means all the `Sender`s associated with this channel
/ have been dropped, no more messages will ever be received.

defs.name: Event
defs.docs: The events generated by the channel event source

attributes.value: / The events generated by the channel event source

defs.name: Sender
defs.docs: The sender end of a channel

attributes.value: / The sender end of a channel
/ It can be cloned and sent accross threads (if `T` is).

defs.name: send
defs.value: pub fn send(&Self, T) -> Result<(), mpsc::SendError<T>>
defs.docs: Send a message to the channel

attributes.value: / Send a message to the channel
/ This will wake the event loop and deliver an `Event::Msg` to
/ it containing the provided value.

defs.name: SyncSender
defs.docs: The sender end of a synchronous channel

attributes.value: / The sender end of a synchronous channel
/ It can be cloned and sent accross threads (if `T` is).

defs.name: send
defs.value: pub fn send(&Self, T) -> Result<(), mpsc::SendError<T>>
defs.docs: Send a message to the synchronous channel

attributes.value: / Send a message to the synchronous channel
/ This will wake the event loop and deliver an `Event::Msg` to
/ it containing the provided value. If the channel is full, this
/ function will block until the event loop empties it and it can
/ deliver the message.
/ Due to the blocking behavior, this method should not be used on the
/ same thread as the one running the event loop, as it could cause deadlocks.

defs.name: try_send
defs.value: pub fn try_send(&Self, T) -> Result<(), mpsc::TrySendError<T>>
defs.docs: Send a message to the synchronous channel

attributes.value: / Send a message to the synchronous channel
/ This will wake the event loop and deliver an `Event::Msg` to
/ it containing the provided value. If the channel is full, this
/ function will return an error, but the event loop will still be
/ signaled for readiness.

/ This is the event source to be inserted into your `EventLoop`.

defs.name: generic
defs.docs: A generic event source wrapping a file descriptor

attributes.value: / A generic event source wrapping a file descriptor
/ You can use this general purpose adapter around file descriptor
/ to insert your own file descriptors into an event loop.
/ It can also help you implementing your own event sources: just have
/ these `Generic<_>` as fields of your event source, and delegate the
/ `EventSource` implementation to them.

defs.name: ping
defs.docs: Ping to the event loop

attributes.value: / Ping to the event loop
/ This is an event source that just produces `()` events whevener
/ the associated `Ping::ping()` method is called. If the event source
/ is pinged multiple times between a single dispatching, it'll only generate
/ one event.
/ This event loop is a simple way of waking up the event loop from an
/ other part of your program (and is what backs the `LoopSignal`). It can
/ also be used as a building block to construct event sources whose source
/ of event is not file descriptor, but rather an userspace source
/ (like an other thread).

defs.name: make_ping
defs.docs: Create a new ping event source

attributes.value: / Create a new ping event source
/ you are given a `Ping` instance, which can be cloned and used to ping the
/ event loop, and a `PingSource`, which you can isnert in your event loop to
/ receive the pings.

defs.name: PingSource
defs.docs: The ping event source

attributes.value: / The ping event source
/ You can insert it in your event loop to receive pings.

defs.name: Ping
defs.docs: The Ping handle

attributes.value: / The Ping handle
/ This handle can be cloned and sent accross threads. It can be used to
/ send pings to the `PingSource`.

defs.name: ping
defs.docs: Send a ping to the `PingSource`

attributes.value: / Send a ping to the `PingSource`

defs.name: signals
defs.docs: Event source for tracking Unix signals

attributes.value: cfg(target_os = "linux")
/ Event source for tracking Unix signals
/ Only available on Linux.
/ This allows you to track  and receive Unix signals through the event loop
/ rather than by registering signal handlers. It uses `signalfd` under the hood.
/ The source will take care of masking and unmasking signals for the thread it runs on,
/ but you are responsible for masking them on other threads if you run them. The simplest
/ way to ensure that is to setup the signal event source before spawning any thread, as
/ they'll inherit their parent signal mask.

attributes.value: / An event generated by the signal event source

attributes.value: / Retrieve the signal number that was receive

attributes.value: / Access the full `siginfo_t` associated with this signal event

defs.name: timer
defs.docs: Timer-based event sources

attributes.value: / Timer-based event sources
/ A `Timer<T>` is a general time-tracking object. It is used by setting timeouts,
/ and generates events whenever a timeout expires.
/ The `Timer<T>` event source provides an handle `TimerHandle<T>`, which is used
/ to set or cancel timeouts. This handle is cloneable and can be send accross threads
/ if `T: Send`, allowing you to setup timeouts from any point of your program.

defs.name: Timer
defs.docs: A Timer event source

attributes.value: / A Timer event source
/ It generates events of type `(T, TimerHandle<T>)`, providing you
/ an handle inside the event callback, allowing you to set new timeouts
/ as a response to a timeout being reached (for reccuring ticks for example).

defs.name: new
defs.docs: Create a new timer with default parameters

attributes.value: / Create a new timer with default parameters
/ Default time resolution is 100ms

defs.name: handle
defs.docs: Get an handle for this timer

attributes.value: / Get an handle for this timer

defs.name: TimerHandle
defs.docs: An handle to a timer, used to set or cancel timeouts

attributes.value: / An handle to a timer, used to set or cancel timeouts
/ This handle can be cloned, and can be sent accross thread as long
/ as `T: Send`.

defs.name: Timeout
defs.docs: An itentifier to cancel a timeout if necessary

attributes.value: / An itentifier to cancel a timeout if necessary

defs.name: add_timeout
defs.value: pub fn add_timeout(&Self, Duration, T) -> Timeout
defs.docs: Set a new timeout

attributes.value: / Set a new timeout
/ The associated `data` will be given as argument to the callback.
/ The returned `Timeout` can be used to cancel it. You can drop it if you don't
/ plan to cancel this timeout.

defs.name: cancel_timeout
defs.docs: Cancel a previsouly set timeout and retrieve the associated data

attributes.value: / Cancel a previsouly set timeout and retrieve the associated data
/ This method returns `None` if the timeout does not exist (it has already fired
/ or has already been cancelled).

defs.name: cancel_all_timeouts
defs.docs: Cancel all planned timeouts for this timer

attributes.value: / Cancel all planned timeouts for this timer
/ All associated data will be dropped.

defs.name: EventSource
defs.docs: Trait representing an event source

attributes.value: / Trait representing an event source
/ This is the trait you need to implement if you wish to create your own
/ calloop-compatible event sources.
/ The 3 type parameter define the type of closure the user will need to
/ provide to process events for your event source.
/ The `process_events` method will be called when one of the FD you registered
/ is ready, with the associated readiness and token.
/ The last 3 methods are plumbing to let your source register itself with the
/ polling system. See their documentation for details.

defs.name: Event
defs.docs: The type of events generated by your source.

attributes.value: / The type of events generated by your source.

defs.name: Metadata
defs.docs: Some metadata of your event source

attributes.value: / Some metadata of your event source
/ This is typically useful if your source contains some internal state that
/ the user may need to interact with when processing events. The user callback
/ will receive a `&mut Metadata` reference.
/ Just set to `()` if not needed.

defs.name: Ret
defs.docs: The return type of the user callback

attributes.value: / The return type of the user callback
/ If the user needs to return some value back to your event source once its
/ processing is finshed (to indicate success or failure for example), you can
/ specify it using this type.
/ Just set to `()` if not needed.

defs.name: process_events
defs.value:
pub fn process_events<F>(&mut Self, Readiness, Token, F)
-> std::io::Result<()> where F: FnMut(Self::Event, &mut Self::Metadata) ->
Self::Ret
defs.docs: Process any relevant events

attributes.value: / Process any relevant events
/ This method will be called every time one of the FD you registered becomes
/ ready, including the readiness details and the associated token.
/ Your event source will then do some processing of the file descriptor(s) to generate
/ events, and call the provided `callback` for each one of them.
/ You should ensure you drained the file descriptors of their events, especially if using
/ edge-triggered mode.

defs.name: register
defs.value: pub fn register(&mut Self, &mut Poll, Token) -> std::io::Result<()>
defs.docs: Register yourself to this poll instance

attributes.value: / Register yourself to this poll instance
/ You should register all your relevant file descriptors to the provided `Poll`
/ using its `Poll::register` method.
/ If you need to register more than one file descriptor, you can change the
/ `sub_id` field of the `Token` to differentiate between them.

defs.name: reregister
defs.value: pub fn reregister(&mut Self, &mut Poll, Token) -> std::io::Result<()>
defs.docs: Re-register your file descriptors

attributes.value: / Re-register your file descriptors
/ Your should update the registration of all your relevant file descriptor to
/ the provided `Poll` using its `Poll::reregister`, if necessary.

defs.name: unregister
defs.value: pub fn unregister(&mut Self, &mut Poll) -> std::io::Result<()>
defs.docs: Unregister your file descriptors

attributes.value: / Unregister your file descriptors
/ You should unregister all your file descriptors from this `Poll` using its
/ `Poll::unregister` method.

defs.name: Source
defs.docs: A token representing an event source inserted in the event loop

attributes.value: / A token representing an event source inserted in the event loop
/ You'll need it to interact with your source via `LoopHandle`

defs.name: Idle
defs.docs: An idle callback that was inserted in this loop

attributes.value: / An idle callback that was inserted in this loop
/ This handle allows you to cancel the callback. Dropping
/ it will *not* cancel it.

defs.name: cancel
defs.docs: Cancel the idle callback if it was not already run

attributes.value: / Cancel the idle callback if it was not already run
